awd_titl_txt: GOALI/Collaborative Research: Improving Patient Flow in Hospitals
awd_abstract_narration:
This Grant Opportunity for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) Program award will advance the national health by reducing congestion and improving patient flow within hospital units and between hospitals.  By developing models that predict flow dynamics and address sources of congestion, this project will improve patient safety and satisfaction, and at the same time reduce staffing and equipment costs to the hospital.  Reduced congestion will also improve occupancy prediction, thus reducing ambulance diversions within the hospital network.  This research employs novel modeling techniques that are informed by a close collaboration between the PIs and the GOALI partner, Northwestern Memorial Hospital (NMH).  Models will be developed that are easy to calibrate and sufficiently general, so that their analyses and insights are applicable in  a broad range of clinical settings within the hospital.  The award provides support for graduate students to engage in research that will be of direct benefit to healthcare operations.  The PIs will incorporate the results of their research in courses on queueing and service engineering.  The outcomes of the research will be disseminated to both the operations research and the healthcare practitioner communities.

This award supports research on multi-server queueing models, tailored specifically to hospital operations, that address key features of patient-flow dynamics.  These features include bursty departures due to periodic discharge windows and non-stationary arrival processes.  Because of the complexity of the dynamics, the research develops appropriate approximations for queueing phenomena based on fluid approximations during peak loads and infinite server approximations during lightly loaded periods.  These methods, in conjunction with high-fidelity simulations, will be used to characterize long-run behavior of the patient-flow process, such as the maximum throughput of hospital units, and their (periodic) time-dependent equilibria behavior under different operational policies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The primary research goal of this project is to improve hospital inpatient flow–a fundamental aspect of hospital operations. To achieve this goal, we develop novel queueing network models to accurately predict patient flow in and across various units in the hospital, which, in addition to providing a better understanding of the system operation, is also used to optimize routing, staffing, and resource allocation policies. The proposed models and assumptions are based on close collaboration with hospitals.

Healthcare spending in the United States is the highest in the world, with hospital-related expenditures taking the lion’s share of the National Health Expenditure. In this context, even moderate improvements in hospital operations can lead to significant savings and have notable economic impacts. The models and analytical tools we developed in this project provide a systematic and scientific way to optimize operational efficiency and improve patient outcomes, especially when facing a limited amount of resources. 

Standard stochastic models may not capture patient-flow dynamics well and therefore may not provide useful insights into related operations. For example, the long-run throughput of inpatient units–one of the key performance measures that hospital managements consider–is a highly non-trivial quantity that depends in a complex manner on the unique features of the service and departure processes in these units and the interconnection with other units in the hospital. Thus, developing new models, that are specifically tailored to the hospital setting is essential. The models we developed are all based on detailed data. We utilize and extend a rigorous data-driven approach to identifying and quantifying key tradeoffs in various operational decisions. This combines advanced econometric tools with queueing-based structural models. We also emphasize that our models and modeling approach are not specific to a hospital, but are applicable to a large set of hospitals.

In addition to the development of new models, we also identify or develop appropriate tools to evaluate and optimize the system's performance. The focus is to gain analytical tractability and derive structural insights. Our results extend periodic equilibrium analysis of non-stationary fluid models and optimal transient control problems with state constraints. We also propose new coupling techniques. These tools and results can be applied to study other complex queueing networks. They are especially useful for systems operating in a non-stationary environment or for transient performance analysis. Time-variability and transient performance optimization are highly relevant in many applications but are less studied compared to stationary systems or long-run average performance measures. 

The project's educational goal includes training graduate students and developing new course materials. Several Ph.D. students have been actively involved in the project. These students not only develop expertise in stochastic modeling, optimal control theory, and data analytics but also gain in-depth domain knowledge in healthcare. The project also provides multiple summer research opportunities for undergraduate and master students. Many of these students continue to pursue their Ph.D. degrees in the STEM field. New materials demonstrating how to apply state-of-art data-driven stochastic modeling tools to improve patient flow in healthcare delivery systems have been incorporated into existing courses.
